body.p: This is the homepage for the free “Linux tn5250” emulator. That’s a bit of a misnomer though, since it works on FreeBSD and any other modern Unix.

tn5250 is a telnet client for the IBM AS/400 that emulates 5250 terminals and printers. This function is the same as that provided by the 5250 emulator in IBM Client Access. There’s even a screenshot here to prove it!
There is a tn5250 FAQ available. It’s a little out of date, but still contains useful information.
Please report any bugs in tn5250 to the mailing list or to the tn5250 SourceForge bug tracker.
The tn5250 project is kindly hosted by SourceForge. Visit the tn5250 SourceForge project page to see all the other tools they give us to work with.
To get the latest stable release of tn5250, visit the tn5250 files list.
If you don’t want to have to compile the program yourself, there are another two options:

ul.li: Red Hat users can download RPMS provided by Henri Gomez.
Debian users have it a little easier — tn5250 is part of the main distribution. You should be able to install it by typing apt-get install tn5250 as root.

body.p: Finally, you can get the latest tn5250 sources from anonymous CVS, or just browse them online.
To check tn5250 out via anonymous CVS, enter the following commands. When asked for a password for ‘anonymous’, just press Enter.
To build tn5250 from CVS, you’ll need automake, autoconf, libtool and ncurses. Run ./autogen.sh, ./configure then make && make install from the checked out directory.

tn5250 development and discussion all happens on the mailing list, provided by MIDRANGE dot COM. You must subscribe to the mailing before you will be able to send email to it, but it’s very low traffic.

ul.li: Subscribe to the linux5250 mailing list.
Read the archives of the tn5250 mailing list.

body.p: There’s a page of links to related documentation on this site.
tn5250j is a 5250 emulator written in Java.
x3270 implements the tn3270 protocol, which is very similar to tn5250.
